title: Something interesting we all missed when we saw Jhin's VO.

replies.body:
Pretext: I am a clinical therapist who has previously done both acute and long-term interventions with people convicted of murder and rape amongst other things.  

I'll be honest, I don't care for Jhin's kit all that much, but the character is frighteningly well developed.  It's actually for this reason that I have so much fun playing him.  There are strong characteristics of multiple mental disorders including Obsessive Compulsive Disorder (the number 4, killing compulsions, etc.) and (what appears to me to be) Bipolar Disorder (the belief that he is perfection incarnate, minimizing his own terrible actions, the laughter upon death, the fact that when he talks to himself you can actually hear multiple instruments which is a metaphor for his elevated position in his own head).  I absolutely love the minor details, such as Jhin humming to himself to assuage his "stage fright" and his inconsistencies when he speaks (aka how he hates killing but he has to).  In reading an article on the development of Jhin, the devs stated that they had to go to a very dark place to come up with these things.  As far as a complete character, Jhin hits home harder than any character Riot has made before.  I actually considered creating a fake case study of Jhin to take to my interns to help with both diagnostic criteria for mental health disorders as well as possible interventions.  And we didn't even cover the fact that he was released from prison and paid off to murder more, which adds a whole other wrinkle to it!  So many more possibilities and discussions!

Wow thanks.   I wasn't gonna comment on this thread as people seemed to be working it out.  But this assessment meant a lot and I felt I had to thank you.  
I did some research before writing Jhin and then tried to make sure that there was some painful vulnerabilities inside that monster.  
He was _unpleasant_ to write from within, and I believe Kyle (sound team) had to take breaks when doing the long days of work on him. 

Thanks again.

This made my day.

Waaarghbobo.
design more champions. hands down. that's all there is too it. idk about anyone else but i love emotional wrecks.

no need for another emotional wreck lest we find ourselves back in 90's alternative, lol. So much angst :P But the level of depth to his character is pretty legit. That we can keep going strong for sure.

Usually when people think insane, they think of someone absolutely hysterical like The Joker or someone religiously insane like Monseigneur Claude Frollo.

But the shocking amount of detail, little tidbits, and depth of character portrayed within Jhin, as well as the fact that he has to memorize everything out loud to believe and verify it, is amazing. Not to mention he might even have to speak aloud to drown out voices in his head, so that could be another factor.

Jhin is, by far, the deepest character you have delved into when it came to detail and mental analysis. And for that, I give Riot a gold star.

I can tell from experience you made an awesome work on Jhin characterization.

I first had to stop by a mental institution as young as 8-years old where I was diagnose with multiple mental illness. I had to take risperidone for years and even today, long after I stopped any appointment, I know I'm not cured. In fact, it might even be worse. Needless to say, some questions keep haunting me. Can I even be cured ? Can you cure someone who was never healthy to begin with ?

Jhin hit close to home. So, no, I'm not killing people and I don't do drugs, but you don't need such spectacular symptoms to feel pain and distress. And as both an artist and someone with mental disorders, I can easely relate to his questioning and suffering. Maybe not exactly in the way you intended him to be, but something similar.

Every one of his line is... perfect :)

As I said before, the accuracy and themes keep me coming back to him.  He is the only champion in this game that I actually turn off my music to listen to the dialogue each and every game.  I will admit that more than a few times, I heard a line, became a bit serendipitous about it and got myself killed by not paying attention :P  And by all means, if there is anything I can do in the future to help you guys write another amazing character like this, I'm just a PM away :)  Thank you for the dedication to your craft.

I'm a licensed clinical social worker (so yes, professional credentials).  Bipolar disorder is an Axis I disorder while Narcissistic Personality Disorder is Axis II.  Any Personality disorder is typically secondary to an Axis I because it is assumed that an Axis II is INHERENT to the person's personality or function.  Bipolar disorder (Both Bipolar I and Bipolar II) can be controlled with both medication and therapy to an extent where as a personality disorder really can't.  In this case, Jhin isn't just narcissistic in nature, he very clearly displays traits of Bipolar Disorder including: Self-inflated grandiosity, racing thoughts, elevated mood/euphoria, and increase in goal-directed activities.  Can we say for certain Jhin has been through a manic phase? Well no, cause he's a video game character.  But if i met him in a clinic, he would likely meet criteria for both disorders.

P.S. I am aware Axis I and II aren't used with DSM 5.  It just makes this whole thing easier to explain.

This is, by far, very accurate of an analysis. I live with people who are psychologists, have delved deep into the subject myself, and have friends who deal with some of those conditions. It's simply amazing how much detail, clarity, and minute aspects of Jhin are portrayed in every single line, tick, and action of his. He's not simply a self-proclaimed artist: he's one that was crafted from insanity so accurate they might as well have found the real deal and had the guy voice Jhin.
There is no performance unless there is someone there to witness it.
What's the fun in making art when there is nobody to see it? An artist cannot critique his own work.

He is a serial murderer with a guilty conscience. It is an archetype in popular culture if not an accurate representation of true serial killers. He feels a compulsion to kill and to make it an art form according to his values, and he feels bad about it... but it's not enough to stop him.  
{{champion:202}}

He's also Obsessive Compulsive (thus his love affair with 4), which means he literally feels compulsions to do things and feels like things will be terrible if he doesn't. He may know it's wrong, but his brain tells him he has to.

Yeah Jhin is like an addict,he knows what he does is bad,but he simply can't stop it.

There are also the quotes:
"I want to feel everything. The gun makes it so I do."
"I can't live without the euphoria of performance."
"It is only when the gun fires that I am alive."

That honestly sounds like he is suffering from depression and like he only feels good when killing.

Honestly I interpret his "the moment before the shot...is painful" as him anticipating pulling the trigger more and more, but for his art he has to wait for just the right moment. He is waiting for that moment, seeing it coming closer and it is paining him. He is so close to release, to put it another way. 

Personally my favorite aspect of him comes from his quote "I get nervous before every performance, but I need that feeling." I did not originally put much stock into it until I noticed that sometimes during the first 1 min 30 seconds he can be heard breathing heavily, humming, whistling or similarly making small noises. Jhin has stagefright at the start of each game.

_...and that's exactly what he wants you to think._

I realized the other night while reading the updated lore that **Jhin sees himself as an artist.** Yes, I know that should be obvious, but really think about it. He sees himself as a creator and a performer, planning meticulous works of grisly and gory art. And like all shows, it must eventually come to an end. But not by simply being captured, no, no.

_"Where's the drama in that?"_ {{champion:202}}

Characters in fiction, even villains, need a reason. Need a story. Whether they have mommy issues or were rendered insane in an experiment gone wrong, villains have a (small) reason for doing what they do, and Jhin does not see himself as an exception. His is a morbid fascination with "Beauty in Death" and he simply cannot help it!

_"...every time I lie"_ {{champion:202}}

...and it is indeed a lie. Jhin feels no remorse whatsoever. He's insane. He's engineered himself a chance at redemption to make the story **_more interesting._** Everyone here has just been lured in by the story of a mentally ill man who yearns for saving from his own madness. We fell for the drama he's written for us.

There's no doubt in my mind that if Jhin were ever truly cornered, if Zed or Shen were moments away from ending his life, that somehow, there'd be a decently sized audience and a method of killing himself available to Jhin. "Finally, the golden demon is defeated! Oh how I've longed for this day. It's been so many years of pain and sorrow, unable to stop myself when every death breaks my heart! But I shall not sully your hands with my death, no. I must have the courage to put such a monster out of everyone's misery myself. I do so regret I hadn't the courage earlier! Goodbye, faithful audience. You'll miss me."

Zed and Shen would spend the rest of the night examining the scene. They'd examine the base of the cliffs and search for the body. Maybe it was a hidden knife or poison, and they'd examine it thoroughly, looking to determine if it was a body double or a really good false death. They'd spend months poring over what happened, wondering if it's really over. They'd spend the rest of their lives wondering if what he said was true.

_This world will never forget the performances of Khada Jhin._

It could very well be a game to him, but it could also be revenge or both.  Narcissists by definition have a deeply held belief that they are better/superior to all others.  The fact that Zed and Shen previously beat him likely left him in a state of shock and disbelief.  On the other hand, even narcissists can recognize "near equals" (as a client of mine once said) and beating those people becomes almost a passion in itself.  And to truly express his "art" he needs to both physically and mentally destroy those who stopped him the first time.  It's very much a case of "suffering for [his] art."  

And as for the hints, Jhin is manipulating Zed and Shen in the Fourth (heh) episode.  Sure he likely wants them dead but he will "pull the string, and they dance" first as I believe the VO line states.  He needs the gratification of winning his own game before he actually wins.
